docs.snippet: THE shiny, spotless Green Cactus Mexican Grill in Stony Brook is a simple place that puts its cards on the table face-up.         The front of its paper menu proclaims "A fresh Mexican experience, no MSG, can openers, microwaves, lard or freezers....
docs.lead_paragraph: THE shiny, spotless Green Cactus Mexican Grill in Stony Brook is a simple place that puts its cards on the table face-up. The front of its paper menu proclaims "A fresh Mexican experience, no MSG, can openers, microwaves, lard or freezers." The back page assures diners that salsas and beans are made fresh daily, chicken breasts are skinless, lean steak is trimmed and chips are made from cholesterol-free canola oil.

docs.snippet: Down the Paseo del Prado they marched, wave after wave of dancers and drummers decked out in extravagant, blindingly flashy outfits. "I've never seen  anything like this before," Oscar Raul Marrero, 11 years old, exulted as he whirled on the sidew...
docs.lead_paragraph: Down the Paseo del Prado they marched, wave after wave of dancers and drummers decked out in extravagant, blindingly flashy outfits. "I've never seen anything like this before," Oscar Raul Marrero, 11 years old, exulted as he whirled on the sidewalk and watched -- wide-eyed, loose-limbed and nimble-footed -- the spectacle flowing past him. After an absence of a quarter of a century, pre-Lenten Carnival has returned to Cuba -- albeit one slightly unhinged from the Christian calendar, by which all festivities were to have been completed before Lent began. By Government decree, Cuba's Carnival will run an extra five days, through Sunday.

headline.main: Havana Journal;Needing Cash for Bread, Cuba Tries a Circus

docs.snippet: The main difference between the Berlin International Film Festival and Europe's two other main movie jamborees is hard to miss. Cannes is in the spring, Venice in the summer and Berlin in the bleak midwinter. With rain and snow sharing top billing...
docs.lead_paragraph: The main difference between the Berlin International Film Festival and Europe's two other main movie jamborees is hard to miss. Cannes is in the spring, Venice in the summer and Berlin in the bleak midwinter. With rain and snow sharing top billing here, the climate is hardly propitious for starlet-gazing. Put differently, this festival is serious business. Perhaps to compensate for this, the festival's longtime director, Moritz de Hadeln, is always eager to draw major screen stars to Berlin. Last year few showed up, so the festival was deemed a flop. This year, things look better. John Travolta, Danny DeVito, Jodie Foster, Emma Thompson and Ian McKellen added glitz in the first few days, while Bruce Willis is expected later.

headline.main: Berlin Fires Up Its Film Festival With Star Power

docs.snippet: The title is a dud. The film is probably 20 minutes too long. Its star has been stuck in the down cycle of an erratic career. The director is a virtual unknown. And even the movie's producer needs several paragraphs to explain what  it's about.   ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The title is a dud. The film is probably 20 minutes too long. Its star has been stuck in the down cycle of an erratic career. The director is a virtual unknown. And even the movie's producer needs several paragraphs to explain what it's about. Yet "Mr. Holland's Opus," a brown shoe of a movie, has been a box-office leader for more than a month now. As of last weekend, it had taken in just over $50 million in ticket sales, a robust performance for a film that cost $23 million.

headline.main: Mr. Holland' Succeeds, Almost Despite Itself

docs.snippet: NEVER mind the gaudy uniforms or the Sgt. Pepper mustaches or the made-up nicknames (Catfish, Blue Moon) or the sheep grazing behind the outfield. That was just Charles O. Finley trying to catch everybody's attention.         He was also a champio...
docs.lead_paragraph: NEVER mind the gaudy uniforms or the Sgt. Pepper mustaches or the made-up nicknames (Catfish, Blue Moon) or the sheep grazing behind the outfield. That was just Charles O. Finley trying to catch everybody's attention. He was also a champion of the designated hitter and night baseball at the World Series. So now you know whom to blame.

headline.main: Sports of The Times;The Owner Knew More Than Stunts

docs.snippet: The main bridge over the Missouri River here stretches nearly a mile before it connects this overwhelmingly white farming town of 4,200 people to the Standing Rock Indian Reservation, where Sitting Bull is buried on a bluff and the vast prairie di...
docs.lead_paragraph: The main bridge over the Missouri River here stretches nearly a mile before it connects this overwhelmingly white farming town of 4,200 people to the Standing Rock Indian Reservation, where Sitting Bull is buried on a bluff and the vast prairie dips and rolls into the horizon. It is also a bridge across time. Mobridge, a working-class city where the best stores and most of the jobs are, is on the eastern side of the river, and sets its clocks by central time. On the western side, where unemployment exceeds 60 percent and the mud after a thaw is ankle deep around the tiny houses scattered across the 900,000-acre reservation, people officially function in mountain time, one hour behind.

docs.snippet: Charles O. Finley, the contentious and colorful former owner of the Oakland A's who challenged baseball tradition by championing changes like bright-colored uniforms and the designated hitter, died yesterday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Ch...
docs.lead_paragraph: Charles O. Finley, the contentious and colorful former owner of the Oakland A's who challenged baseball tradition by championing changes like bright-colored uniforms and the designated hitter, died yesterday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. He was 77. Finley, who lived on a farm in LaPorte, Ind., died of heart and vascular disease, from which he had been suffering for years, said a hospital spokeswoman, Lauri Sanders.

headline.main: Charles O. Finley, Baseball Team Owner Who Challenged Traditions, Diesat 77

docs.snippet: The first Academy Award for best actress was given in 1928 to Janet Gaynor for her performances in three films, including "Street Angel," in which she played a prostitute. Her rival for the Oscar was Gloria Swanson, who starred in  "Sadie Thompson...
docs.lead_paragraph: The first Academy Award for best actress was given in 1928 to Janet Gaynor for her performances in three films, including "Street Angel," in which she played a prostitute. Her rival for the Oscar was Gloria Swanson, who starred in "Sadie Thompson," about a woman who was, well, pretty loose in her morals. A few years later Helen Hayes won the award for "The Sin of Madelon Claudet," in which she played an unwed mother who was viewed as, yes, a prostitute.

headline.main: Play a Hooker and Win an Oscar
